Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting‑time order upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that the requested modification is in the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996); Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses modification of an existing custody order under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and explicitly states that a Probate Court judge may modify a prior custody judgment upon finding (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the children. The court applies this standard to uphold the finding of a material change but reverses on the best‑interests analysis, thereby affirming the two‑part test described in the proposition.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ … When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting‑time order upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that the requested modification is in the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996); Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rolde v. Rolde is an appeal from an original divorce judgment addressing initial custody and visitation, not a proceeding to modify an existing custody or parenting-time order under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The court applies only the general ‘best interests of the child’ standard in determining custody and visitation; it does not discuss, apply, or require a threshold showing of a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ since a prior judgment. Thus, Rolde does not provide authority for the specific two‑part modification standard stated in the proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting‑time determination is the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843–44 (2003); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1996); Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225–26 (1998).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ standard as the governing principle in custody determinations and describes it as the long‑standing, paramount concern in such cases. The court frames its entire analysis of the custody award under this standard, confirming that the child’s best interests are the controlling and primary consideration in custody and parenting‑time decisions.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002)… Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’)… The required considerations… neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider….”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting‑time determination is the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843–44 (2003); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1996); Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225–26 (1998).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt focuses on domestic violence, its impact on children, and the need for explicit findings regarding that impact in custody decisions. It does not clearly articulate the general standard that the paramount consideration in custody or parenting‑time determinations is the best interests of the child, nor does it contain the usual Massachusetts formulation of that principle. While best interests are implicitly at stake, the opinion segment here does not itself state or frame the rule in those terms, so it is a weak authority for the specific proposition as quoted.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. … [A]buse of any family member affects other family members and must be considered in determining the best interests of the child in connection with any order concerning custody.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting‑time determination is the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843–44 (2003); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1996); Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225–26 (1998).
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the post-unfitness question as determining which placement is in the child’s best interests, citing the governing statute, and repeatedly treats the child’s best interests as the controlling, outcome‑determinative standard in the custody/adoption choice. While the case is in the adoption/care‑and‑protection context rather than divorce, it clearly affirms that the dispositive consideration in such custody/placement decisions is the child’s best interests, consistent with the proposition.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … Presented with more than one potential adoption placement, the judge’s task is to determine which plan will serve the best interests of the child…”

Delmolino v. Nance, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 20.raw_text: Delmolino v. Nance, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 209, 210–11 (1982)
Delmolino v. Nance, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 20.proposition: In determining whether to modify custody and parenting time, the Court may consider events occurring since the prior judgment that show that the assumptions underlying the existing order are no longer valid. See Delmolino v. Nance, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 209, 210–11 (1982); Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. at 736–38.
Delmolino v. Nance, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 20.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standard for modifying custody, emphasizing that an original custody judgment is presumed correct and that a judge must find a relevant change in circumstances sufficient to justify transfer of custody. However, it does not frame this in terms of considering post-judgment events that undermine the assumptions underlying the prior order; instead, it finds that even with the move to Ohio there was no such relevant change shown. The case therefore supports the need for a substantial change in circumstances, but not the more specific proposition about reconsidering underlying assumptions based on subsequent events.
Delmolino v. Nance, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 20.relevant_excerpt: For decades, it has been the law that the original judgment awarding custody to a parent is presumed to have been correct… and that before a judge can order a transfer of custody from one parent to another, he must affirmatively find that there is a relevant change in circumstances… [T]hat change must be of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child]… In sum, there is nothing in the record that shows any relevant change in circumstances that would justify the transfer of custody ordered in this case.

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766\u.proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority to tailor custody and parenting‑time orders, including orders for supervised or conditional parenting time, to protect the child and advance the child’s best interests. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; G.L. c. 215, § 6; Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766–67 (1983); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191 (1998).
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766\u.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on procedural defects in using a care-and-protection proceeding to resolve what was essentially a private custody/guardianship dispute, and on the substantive standards for removing a child from a natural parent. It does not discuss the scope of a court’s equitable authority to craft custody or parenting‑time orders, nor mention supervised or conditional parenting time. The case is about when and how custody may be transferred from a parent due to unfitness, not about tailoring visitation conditions, so it does not support the specific proposition cited.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766\u.relevant_excerpt: “Custody is not to be transferred from the natural parent simply because another prospective custodian is thought to be better qualified. A comparison of the advantage the prospective custodian may offer to the child with those that may be offered by the natural parents is inappropriate. … ‘State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.’ … ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191.proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority to tailor custody and parenting‑time orders, including orders for supervised or conditional parenting time, to protect the child and advance the child’s best interests. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; G.L. c. 215, § 6; Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766–67 (1983); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191 (1998).
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with child support, security/attachment to secure support and college expenses, and a modification of legal custody. It does state that Probate and Family Court judges have broad discretion to fashion divorce judgments to protect children’s interests, but it does not address parenting‑time/visitation structure or supervised or conditional parenting time. Thus, while it supports broad equitable discretion in child‑related orders generally, it is not specific authority for tailoring custody and parenting‑time orders such as supervised visitation.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191.relevant_excerpt: “A Probate and Family Court judge has ‘broad discretion to fashion judgments in divorce proceedings that will best protect the interests and welfare of the parties’ minor children.’ Pare v. Pare, 409 Mass. 292, 298-299 (1991). The exact form of the order (or the decision to enter an order at all) is also within the judge’s broad discretion.”

Adoption of Quentin, 424 Mass. 882, 886\.proposition: Where there is credible evidence that a parent’s substance use or intoxication may impair judgment or compromise the safety of the child, the Court may impose safeguards, conditions, or supervision on that parent’s contact with the child. See Adoption of Quentin, 424 Mass. 882, 886–88 (1997); Adoption of Carlos, 413 Mass. 339, 350–52 (1992); Adoption of Elena, 446 Mass. 24, 30–31 (2006).
Adoption of Quentin, 424 Mass. 882, 886\.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses parental unfitness, neglect, itinerant lifestyle, and sexual abuse, but it does not address imposing safeguards, conditions, or supervision on a parent’s *contact* with the child based on substance use or intoxication. Substance use is mentioned only as part of the father’s misuse of public assistance funds to buy drugs and the broader unfitness analysis, and the remedy ultimately imposed is termination/dispensing with consent, not conditional or supervised visitation. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about imposing safeguards or supervised contact due to substance-related safety concerns.
Adoption of Quentin, 424 Mass. 882, 886\.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that there was adequate evidence to support the findings that: the parents maintained an unsafe and unsanitary home and failed to take steps to correct these conditions; the parents lived an itinerant lifestyle which was harmful to the children; they neglected the emotional well-being of the children; the father never displayed a long-term commitment to stay with the family; the father used the public assistance funds to purchase drugs; the mother lacked the ability to protect the children from the father’s harmful conduct; and the mother lacked the capacity to deal with the needs of the children.

Adoption of Carlos, 413 Mass. 339, 350\u.proposition: Where there is credible evidence that a parent’s substance use or intoxication may impair judgment or compromise the safety of the child, the Court may impose safeguards, conditions, or supervision on that parent’s contact with the child. See Adoption of Quentin, 424 Mass. 882, 886–88 (1997); Adoption of Carlos, 413 Mass. 339, 350–52 (1992); Adoption of Elena, 446 Mass. 24, 30–31 (2006).
Adoption of Carlos, 413 Mass. 339, 350\u.support_reasoning: The opinion in Adoption of Carlos concerns standards for terminating parental rights and the court’s ability to consider future parental fitness; it does not discuss parental substance use, intoxication, or the imposition of safeguards or supervised contact based on such concerns. Nothing in the cited pages (350–52) establishes a principle about conditioning or supervising parental contact due to substance-related safety risks. Accordingly, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Adoption of Carlos, 413 Mass. 339, 350\u.relevant_excerpt: “Differently from the Appeals Court, we think that, in weighing the question whether parental rights are to be irrevocably terminated, it is appropriate for a judge to consider whether, on the basis of credible evidence, there is a reasonable likelihood that the parent’s unfitness at the time of trial may be only temporary. A judge may properly be guided by evidence demonstrating reason to believe that a parent will correct a condition or weakness that currently disables the parent from serving his or her child’s best interests.”

Adoption of Elena, 446 Mass. 24, 30\u201.proposition: Where there is credible evidence that a parent’s substance use or intoxication may impair judgment or compromise the safety of the child, the Court may impose safeguards, conditions, or supervision on that parent’s contact with the child. See Adoption of Quentin, 424 Mass. 882, 886–88 (1997); Adoption of Carlos, 413 Mass. 339, 350–52 (1992); Adoption of Elena, 446 Mass. 24, 30–31 (2006).
Adoption of Elena, 446 Mass. 24, 30\u201.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns termination of parental rights based on longstanding substance abuse and whether the resulting unfitness is temporary or likely to continue. It does not discuss fashioning conditions, safeguards, supervision, or limited/structured contact for a substance‑using parent; instead, it affirms complete termination. While it recognizes that drug addiction can be a chronic condition justifying termination, it does not provide authority for the narrower proposition that a court may impose conditions or supervision on a parent’s contact with the child based on substance use.
Adoption of Elena, 446 Mass. 24, 30\u201.relevant_excerpt: “‘[A] condition which is reasonably likely to continue for a prolonged indeterminate period, such as alcohol or drug addiction . . . [that] makes the parent . . . unlikely to provide minimally acceptable care of the child’ is not a temporary condition. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c) (xii). … The judge’s finding that it was ‘doubtful’ that she could ‘maintain successful recovery and care for three very young children’ and his conclusion that the mother’s ‘unfitness is likely to continue into the indefinite future to a near certitude’ are based on appropriate consideration of the evidence and are not clearly erroneous.”
